title: 114_s1599
content: The Act titled "Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2015" amends the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 to include anti-retaliation protection for whistleblowers. The Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2015 provides whistleblower protections for employees, contractors, subcontractors, and agents. Employers are prohibited from discriminating against individuals who report violations of antitrust laws to the employer or the Federal Government. The Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2015 protects whistleblowers who report antitrust violations to the employer or Federal Government. Covered individuals are safeguarded from retaliation for reporting violations or assisting in investigations. The Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2015 protects whistleblowers from retaliation for reporting antitrust violations or assisting in investigations. Covered individuals are safeguarded unless they planned and initiated a violation of the antitrust laws. The Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act of 2015 protects whistleblowers from retaliation for reporting antitrust violations or assisting in investigations. Covered individuals are safeguarded unless they planned and initiated a violation of the antitrust laws, including obstruction of a Department of Justice investigation. Definitions include antitrust laws, covered individual, and employer. The term 'employer' includes individuals such as officers, employees, contractors, subcontractors, or agents. The term 'Federal Government' refers to regulatory or law enforcement agencies, Members of Congress, or congressional committees. The term 'person' has the same meaning as in the Clayton Act. The term 'violation' under antitrust laws does not include civil violations that are not also criminal violations. A covered individual alleging discharge or discrimination by an employer in violation of the law can seek relief by filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor or bringing a legal action in court if no decision is made within 180 days. The procedure involves filing a complaint with specific guidelines. The procedure for filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor regarding discharge or discrimination is governed by specific rules and procedures outlined in section 42121(b) of title 49, United States Code. Notification must be made to the individual named in the complaint and the employer. Legal burdens of proof and statute of limitations are also specified in the process. The procedure for filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor regarding discharge or discrimination is outlined in section 42121(b) of title 49, United States Code. A civil action can be brought to enforce the order in the district court if there is a failure to comply. A covered individual prevailing in any action shall be entitled to all necessary relief. A civil action can be brought to enforce the order in the district court if there is a failure to comply. A covered individual prevailing in any action shall be entitled to all necessary relief, including reinstatement, back pay with interest, and compensation for special damages related to discrimination. Whistleblowers retain their rights under Federal or State law and collective bargaining agreements. The Senate passed S. 1599 on July 22, 2015, providing anti-retaliation protections for antitrust whistleblowers.
